section.hand:
To M
r
Secret
y
De
c
18. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 18 Decem
b
To M
r
Secretary
Yt may please yo
r
H.
e prisonner
Vasseur
is at length delivered
but w
th
very much trouble & sute as
e bearer hereof
S
r
William Russels
servaunt, who hath folowed yt long w
th
exceeding great paines can
c
r
tify yo
r
H. who hath also
e copie of
e sentence wh
r
by they bannishe
him out of these Provinces for the space of 3 yeares. By a
s
vaunt of
M
r
Vicechamb
r
layne
I Rxd two from yo
r
H. 3 daies past, one was of
the 26 & the oth
r
of the 28 of Nove
m
& a third from my
LL.
of the
counsell of the 17 of
e same moneth: wh
r
in I am required to declare
unto
e
generall states
, what order hir
Ma
tie
hath taken for the
repairing
e breaches at
Ostend,
w
ch
I minde to do at their next
assembly, & will signifie theyr answere. I have also made knowne
to
e
counsell of State
hir Ma
ties
liecnce graunted to my
L. Burgh
, for
his retourne for a time, & for
Cap
t
Price
to Governe in his absence
wherunto they used no speech but onely set yt downe for a note in theyr
register. It is adv
r
tized hether out of
Gelderland,
that the waters are
risen so high in those quarters, that the Ennemies fort
about
Berck
&
Rees
are in dang
r
to be caried awaie, about fornight since the
count Harmon van Berghen
finding a fitt opportunity by meanes of
e
frost made a roade into
Friseland
& burned a c
r
taine Dorpe not farr
fr
o
Le ewarden.
But retourning back as hee passed by a watch house
him self was hurt, with a muscket shott & Villiers
e Gov
r
no
r
of
Steinwick
& some few besides of his company slayne. It freeseth at this p
nt
very hard in these countreys, & yf yt so continew
e English troupes
that ar in
Holland
must againe toward
Gorchum.
Also this frost
doth let
e conveyance of l
re
s betweene mee &
Joest v
a
Cleve
of
Embden
about
e matt
r
of
Groeninghen,
wh
r
of I do expect by his next letter,
t
I
shal be able to conjecture what good effect will ensew. For he hath
tlye
already broken
e ice, having writen about yt to some principal
sons
that ar in Groenighen, who have also returned a frindly answer, &
cured him a pasport of
e towne to repaire thith
r
unto them, or oth
r
wise
they offer to send some fytt
son to Embden to confer w
th
them ther.
& yt was his purpose w
th
in six daies after
e dispatch of his last unto mee.
w
ch
was written 6 weekes past to send my lre wherof long sins I sent
Yo
r
H.
e copie, into
e towne. so as by his next I hope to have
somewhat of more worth to adv
r
tize yo
r
H. If those w
th
in to whom hee
hath written do not seek to entrappe him (w
ch
hee is circumspect enough
& wanting no advise to forsee) there ys sufficient cause to hope for a happy
sequel, or at least of some distourbance in the Ennemies courses,
My writing in this matter to
e gentlemen of Frise upon
Persivals
speeches
was to great expense of time w
th
out any frute. For I attended a great
while for theyr directions, w
ch
proved in
e end to bee
e same, that I had
put in practise before w
th
Joest van cleve. It is a good counsel unto meethat yo
r
H. doth intimate of her Ma
ties
intention at my
L. of Buckhursts
coming hether, to make a
fect triall, howe this people doth stand united
unto her. I doo finde yt oth
r
wise for mine owne
te a most wearisome
place of
s
vice not knowing where hir Ma
ty
could send mee, where I would
not goe w
th
more willingnes & farr bett
r
hope to give hir Hig
nes
satisfaction w
th
some frute of my travels I had never no hope in this place
as your H. understood mee of a
fect correspondence. For I knowe yt is
unpossible as long as some have
e swaye. But I am forced heer to holde yt
for a
te of good correspondence, if her Ma
ties
subjects & ministers may bee
entreated in such competent good sort, as they may not bee driven by meanes
of theyr badd usage, to refuse to do them
s
vice. For by yo
r
H. letters heertofore
& by hir Ma
ties
courses I have alwaies found yt a matter of infinite daunger
fol.211v
if her Hig
nes
should w
th
drawe her forces from hence & yet unles her
Ma
ty
make showe of some actuall
ceeding yn
t
respect I see no
oth
r
waye but
t
her Hig
nes
must
force continew hir wonted patience [&]
s
ve hir owne tourne for
e time, & w
th
stand
e common ennemy w
th
such
a froward correspondence as ys heer at this p
nt
.
I have had no conference yet w
th
Paul Bus
, to whom
M
r
Gilpin
hath D
l
yo
r
l
re
, hee hath many times made
mis to come unto mee, but is
abode is at
Leyden
& one thing or other doth put him still from his
purpose.Upon
e receyt of yo
r
H. l
re
he hath appointed w
th
out faile
to bee w
th
mee very shortly, But what hee will im
t I cannot conjecture.
Hee ys much discontented w
th
e state as well as others, and can
better brooke of any man then of
Barnevelt,
who suceeded
advocat after him.
